communications.subject: Michigan Freedom of Information Act Request: Foia Request-Investments
communications.communication:
To Whom It May Concern:

Pursuant to the Michigan Freedom of Information Act, I hereby request the following records:

Hello,

I am currently seeking updated quarterly performance data from Kent District Library Employees’ Retirement System alternative asset holdings for the following date(s): 1Q25

As always, thank you in advance for the time you take in sending me the responsive documents. Please feel free to let me know if there is anything i can do on my side to make this process easier for you.

On behalf of PitchBook Data, Inc., under the Michigan Freedom of Information Act,I request a copy of the quarterly public record from 1Q25 from the following information, preferably in Excel or PDF format.

1. Names and vintage years of all private equity, venture capital, mezzanine, distressed, real estate/REIT, debt and infrastructure partnerships in your plan’s portfolio.
2. Commitments made to each partnership.
3. Contributions drawn down since inception.
4. Distributions made to Kent District Library Employees’ Retirement System to date by each individual partnership.
5. Net Asset Value of each partnership.
6. Internal rates of return (IRRs) for each partnership with and without the use of credit facility. Please note if the IRRs are not net.
7. Investment multiple (TV/PI) for each individual partnership.
8. The dollar amount of “total management fees and costs paid” for each individual partnership.
9. Date as of which all the above data was calculated.
10. Names of all alternative asset partnerships partially and fully sold by Kent District Library Employees’ Retirement System including date of sale.
11. For each fund, please indicate whether or not the fund uses Subscription Credit Facilities.

I also request a copy of any disclosable documents which contain some or all of the following information:
12. Names of all hedge fund holdings (including hedge fund of funds) in Kent District Library Employees’ Retirement System portfolio.
13. Month by Month Market Value for each hedge fund holding (including hedge fund of funds) since Kent District Library Employees’ Retirement System initial investment up to 1Q25.
14. Month by Month Contributions to each hedge fund holding (including hedge fund of funds) since Kent District Library Employees’ Retirement System initial investment up to 1Q25.
15. Month by Month Returns (net of fees) earned by Kent District Library Employees’ Retirement System for each hedge fund holding (including hedge fund of funds) since initial investment up to 1Q25.
16. Investment memorandum used by the Kent District Library Employees’ Retirement System investment committee and investment consultants providing consultation to the Kent District Library Employees’ Retirement System regarding private equity, venture capital, mezzanine, distressed, real estate/REIT, debt and infrastructure partnerships being considered for investment by the Kent District Library Employees’ Retirement System portfolio.
17. All due diligence materials and presentation materials produced by the General Partners in the course of the Kent District Library Employees’ Retirement System conducting due diligence on investments into any private equity, venture capital, mezzanine, distressed, real estate/REIT, debt and infrastructure partnerships.
18. For each fund, please indicate whether or not the fund uses Subscription Credit Facilities.
If there are any fees for searching for, reviewing, or copying the records, please inform me before you task the request. If you deny all or any part of this request, please cite each specific exemption you think justifies your refusal to release the information and notify me of appeal procedures available under the law.

Best Regards,
Roshan

The requested documents will be made available to the general public, and this request is not being made for commercial purposes.

In the event that there are fees, I would be grateful if you would inform me of the total charges in advance of fulfilling my request. I would prefer the request filled electronically, by e-mail attachment if available or CD-ROM if not.

Thank you in advance for your anticipated cooperation in this matter. I look forward to receiving your response to this request within 5 business days, as the statute requires.

Sincerely,

Jake Hujar
Requested attached.

title: Request for Correctional Mental Health Staff Directory and Contact Information (Department of Corrections)

communications.subject: The Missouri Sunshine Law Request: Request for Correctional Mental Health Staff Directory and Contact Information (Department of Corrections)
communications.communication:
To Whom It May Concern:

Pursuant to the The Missouri Sunshine Law, I hereby request the following records:

I am requesting a list of currently employed mental health professionals within your state's Department of Corrections or its subsidiary agencies, as well as their contact information.

Specifically, I am requesting:

- Full names
- Job titles
- Assigned correctional facility
- Government-issued email addresses
- Government-issued phone numbers (direct desk numbers if available, otherwise department phone numbers with or without extensions)
- Department/division (e.g. Behavioral Health, Mental Health Services)

This request applies to the following roles: rehabilitative program coordinators, licensed psychologists, psychiatrists, clinical social workers, and other licensed mental health professionals serving incarcerated populations in state-operated facilities.

If available, I request this information be provided in a machine-readable format such as CSV or Excel.

The requested documents will be made available to the general public, and this request is not being made for commercial purposes.

In the event that there are fees, I would be grateful if you would inform me of the total charges in advance of fulfilling my request. I would prefer the request filled electronically, by e-mail attachment if available or CD-ROM if not.

Thank you in advance for your anticipated cooperation in this matter. I look forward to receiving your response to this request within 3 business days, as the statute requires.

Sincerely,

Andrew Ma

communications.subject: RE: The Missouri Sunshine Law Request #MR 186605
communications.communication:
Dear Matt,

Thank you for your quick assistance.

I understand that Missouri DOC contracts its medical and mental health services through Centurion Health. I’m reaching out to respectfully request the following:
	1.	The name and email address of the relevant Centurion Health point of contact for mental or behavioral health services in Missouri DOC facilities.
	2.	The name(s) and contact information for MDOC personnel who oversee mental health programming or coordinate external rehabilitative initiatives, particularly those involving mindfulness, trauma-informed care, or wellness programming.

I’m currently conducting outreach to explore interest in offering a free, evidence-based meditation program for incarcerated individuals. To do so responsibly, I’d like to speak with the appropriate individuals — whether within Centurion or MDOC — to understand if this might be aligned with existing priorities.

I’m not requesting any confidential records, only public-facing professional contact information.

Thanks again for your time and support.

Warmly,
Andrew Ma
Vipassana Prison Trust

communications.subject: RE: The Missouri Sunshine Law Request #MR 186605
communications.communication:
The current Centurion Contract can be obtained at the following website: Contract Board | MissouriBUYS Statewide eProcurement System<https://missouribuys.mo.gov/contractboard>

You will need to search for the following contract information:
CS210318001 for Centurion.

communications.subject: RE: The Missouri Sunshine Law Request #MR 186605
communications.communication:
Thank you for providing this information! Do you have any information on the second part of the revised request? 

2. The name(s) and contact information for MDOC personnel who oversee mental health programming or coordinate external rehabilitative initiatives, particularly those involving mindfulness, trauma-informed care, or wellness programming.

These would be individuals who work directly with Centurion in the individual facilities themselves. 

Andrew

communications.subject: RE: The Missouri Sunshine Law Request #MR 186605
communications.communication: I am not sure what you are asking, but if it cannot be obtained from Centurion, I believe this information can be found on our website:  www.doc.mo.gov.

communications.subject: RE: The Missouri Sunshine Law Request #MR 186605
communications.communication:
Got it - thank you! It seems the person I'm looking for is Annie Herman, Director of Rehabilitative Services within MDOC. I have her phone number from the website you shared, but do you have a working email address I can use to send her a message?

Thank you very much, 

Andrew

communications.subject: Oklahoma Open Records Act Request: Oklahoma DOC transgender policies
communications.communication:
To Whom It May Concern:

Pursuant to the Oklahoma Open Records Act, I hereby request the following records:

All department policy and guidance documents regarding transgender inmates, including but not limited to gender-affirming medical care, housing and treatment by staff. I also request records of any proposed and/or enacted changes to said policies made on or after Nov. 6, 2024 until date of search, if such documents exist.

I request that, if appropriate, fees be waived as I believe this request is in the public interest. The requested documents will be made available to the general public free of charge as part of the public information service at MuckRock.com, processed by a representative of the news media/press and is made in the process of news gathering and not for commercial usage.

In the event that there are fees, I would be grateful if you would inform me of the total charges in advance of fulfilling my request. I would prefer the request filled electronically, by e-mail attachment if available or CD-ROM if not.

Thank you in advance for your anticipated cooperation in this matter. I look forward to receiving your response to this request within 10 business days.

Sincerely,

Ileana Garnand

communications.subject: New Mexico Inspection of Public Records Act Request: Alternative Response Unit Roster
communications.communication:
To Whom It May Concern:

Pursuant to the New Mexico Inspection of Public Records Act, I hereby request the following records:

A complete and current roster of all former and current employees of the Alternative Response Unit, including for each employee:

Full name
Age
Gender
Race
Job title
Department or division
Work email address (if available)
Date of hire (if available and non-exempt)
Date of termination (if relevant)

If any of the above fields are exempt from disclosure, please redact only the exempt information and release the remainder of the records in accordance with the partial disclosure provisions of applicable public records law. I am not requesting any personally identifiable information that is protected by law, such as Social Security numbers or personal contact information.

I would prefer to receive this information in electronic format (e.g., CSV, Excel, or PDF) if available.

If there are any fees for searching or copying the records, please inform me before processing the request. I also request a waiver of fees as the information is being sought for research and public interest purposes, not for commercial use.

The requested documents will be made available to the general public, and this request is not being made for commercial purposes.

In the event that there are fees, I would be grateful if you would inform me of the total charges in advance of fulfilling my request. I would prefer the request filled electronically, by e-mail attachment if available or CD-ROM if not.

Thank you in advance for your anticipated cooperation in this matter. I look forward to receiving your response to this request within 15 business days, as the statute requires.

Sincerely,

Filed Requests

communications.subject: Your City of Santa Fe public records request #25-2929 has been submitted.
communications.communication:
City of Santa Fe ************************************************************************ Your record request #25-2929 has been submitted successfully. Thank you for your interest in public records from the City of Santa Fe. Your request has been received and is being processed in accordance with the New Mexico Inspection of Public Records Act (NMSA 1978, Section 14-2-1 et seq.). Your request will be internally directed to the relevant department(s) to locate any responsive material we may have. If responsive documents are readily available, we will provide copies of those records immediately. If records are not available within 15 calendar days of your request, you will be notified with an updated estimate of when your records will be available. Please be advised that requests for body worn and dash camera footage may take a significant time to review and provide as a 30 minute video may take up to 2 hours to review depending on the type(s) of redactions that may need to be applied. You can monitor the status of your request at any time by logging in to NextRequest and reviewing the assigned reference number for your request. If you provided an email address in your original request, all updates and notifications regarding your request will also be sent via email. Gracias por su interés en los registros públicos de la Ciudad de Santa Fe. Su solicitud ha sido recibida y está siendo procesada de acuerdo con la Ley de Inspección de Registros Públicos de Nuevo México (NMSA 1978, Sección 14-2-1 et seq.). Su solicitud se dirigirá internamente a los departamentos pertinentes para localizar cualquier material responsivo que podamos tener. Si los documentos de respuesta están disponibles, le proporcionaremos copias de esos registros de inmediato. Si los registros no están disponibles dentro de los 15 días calendario posteriores a su solicitud, se le notificará con una estimación actualizada de cuándo estarán disponibles sus registros. Tenga en cuenta que las solicitudes de imágenes corporales y de cámara de tablero pueden tardar un tiempo considerable en revisarse y proporcionarse, ya que un video de 30 minutos, puede demorar hasta 2 horas en revisarse, según los tipos de redacciones que puedan necesitar aplicarse. Puede monitorear el estado de su solicitud en cualquier momento iniciando sesión en NextRequest y revisando el número de referencia asignado a su solicitud. Si proporcionó una dirección de correo electrónico en su solicitud original, todas las actualizaciones y notificaciones relacionadas con su solicitud también se enviarán por correo electrónico. ************************************************************************ Reply to this email or sign in to contact City of Santa Fe.

Change your email settings | Visit our help center

title: ATTN: FOIA request from Business Insider

communications.subject: Freedom of Information Act Request: ATTN: FOIA request from Business Insider
communications.communication:
To Whom It May Concern:

Pursuant to the Freedom of Information Act, I hereby request the following records:

-- Copies of any and all communications, including emails, email attachments, text messages, voicemails, and memos, held by the Department of Veterans Affairs referencing the Department of Government Efficiency’s “DOGE” access to agency data systems and records
-- The list of Department of Government Efficiency “DOGE” employees with a “@va.gov” email domain

Please provide records from 01/20/25 through the date this request is processed.

For reference, according to news reports, VA leaders confirmed that they're working with DOGE officials for purposes of "identifying wasteful contracts, improving VA operations and strengthening management of the department's IT projects." Please make sure to provide names and contact info for those DOGE officials: https://www.militarytimes.com/veterans/2025/02/06/va-leaders-working-with-doge-but-say-veterans-personal-info-is-secure/ 

I would like these records in electronic format, transmitted via email or other digital method; please refrain from sending paper copies of the records.

If you determine that any of the information qualifies for an exemption from disclosure, I ask you to note whether the exemption is discretionary, and if so whether it is necessary in this case to exercise your discretion to withhold the information. In any event, please provide a signed notification citing the legal authorities on which you rely if you determine that any of the information is exempt and will not be disclosed.

Please waive any applicable fees; this information is being sought for reporting purposes. As I am making this request as a journalist and this information is timely, I would appreciate your communicating with me by telephone if you have questions regarding this request. If I can provide any clarification that will help expedite the processing of my request, please contact me directly at 714-833-8487.

The requested documents will be made available to the general public, and this request is not being made for commercial purposes.

In the event that there are fees, I would be grateful if you would inform me of the total charges in advance of fulfilling my request. I would prefer the request filled electronically, by e-mail attachment if available or CD-ROM if not.

Thank you in advance for your anticipated cooperation in this matter. I look forward to receiving your response to this request within 20 business days, as the statute requires.

Sincerely,

Nicole Einbinder

communications.subject: FOIA 25-08907-F: Initial Agency Decision
communications.communication:
May 20, 2025                                                                                                        In Reply Refer To: 001B
                                                                                                                                   FOIA Request: 25-08907-F

Nicole Einbinder
MuckRock News, DEPT MR181257
263 Huntington Ave
Boston, MA 02115
181257-75105528@requests.muckrock.com<mailto:181257-75105528@requests.muckrock.com>

Dear Ms. Einbinder,

This is the Initial Agency Decision to your Freedom of Information Act (FOIA) request to the Office of the Secretary, U.S. Dept. of Veterans Affairs (OSVA) dated and received February 6, 2025, and assigned FOIA tracking number 25-08907-F.  You requested, as quoted,

  *   "Copies of any and all communications, including emails, email attachments, text messages, voicemails, and memos, held by the Department of Veterans Affairs referencing the Department of Government Efficiency's "DOGE" access to agency data systems and records
  *   The list of Department of Government Efficiency "DOGE" employees with a "@va.gov" email domain."

Searches Dated 2/27/25, 2/28/25, 3/10/25, 3/20/25, 4/9/25, & 4/11/25
On February 27, 2025, our search cut-off date, an OSVA FOIA Officer searched through the VA Integrated Enterprise Workflow Solution (VIEWS), VA's official information system for interagency memoranda, agreement, access requests, contracts.  An OSVA FOIA Officer used the following search terms: DOGE AND ("information sharing").  On February 28, 2025, an OSVA FOIA Officer searched through VIEWS with the following search terms: DOGE AND access.

On March 10, 2025, our search cut-off date, an OSVA FOIA Officer requested that the VA Office of Information & Technology (OI&T), Identity and Access Management (IAM) office search for and provide a list of VA information systems that Mr. Justin Fulcher, a Senior Advisor to the Chief of Staff and VA Liaison to DOGE, accessed including the last accessed date.  On March 20, 2025, an OSVA FOIA Officer requested that the VA OI&T IAM office search for the same information for Mr. Cary Volpert, another Senior Advisor to the Chief of Staff and VA Liaison to DOGE.

On March 31, 2025, and April 7, 2025, the OI&T IAM office provided such list.  None of the information systems accessed are VHA or VBA Privacy Act Systems of Records.

On April 9, 2025, an OSVA FOIA Officer searched through VIEWS for Inter-Agency Agreements, Memoranda of Understanding, Memoranda of Agreement, and Inter-Agency Contracts.  On April 9, 2025, an OSVA FOIA Officer used the following search terms: "DOGE" AND ("agreement" OR "understanding").

On April 11, 2025, an OSVA FOIA Officer searched through VIEWS with the following search terms:

  1.  "DOGE" AND "contract";
  2.  ("Government Efficiency") AND ("agreement" OR "understanding" OR "contract"); and,
  3.  ("Digital Service") AND ("agreement" OR "understanding" OR "contract").
Our searches through VIEWS dated February 27, 2025, February 28, 2025, April 9, 2025, and April 11, 2025 yielded no responsive records.

All-Other Fee Category
We have placed you in the all-other category.  For this FOIA request, OSVA does not charge any FOIA fees.  OSVA reserves the right to charge FOIA fees for any future FOIA requests.

Initial Agency Decision
Please find attached two (2) pages, which the VA releases in full.  Mr. Fulcher and Mr. Volpert have not accessed any VHA or VBA Privacy Act Systems of Records.

FOIA Mediation
As part of the 2007 FOIA amendments, the Office of Government Information Services (OGIS) was created to offer mediation services to resolve disputes between FOIA requesters and Federal agencies as a non-exclusive alternative to litigation. Using OGIS services does not affect your right to pursue litigation. Under the provisions of the FOIA Improvement Act of 2016, the following contact information is provided to assist FOIA requesters in resolving disputes:
VA Central Office FOIA Public Liaison:
Email Address: vacofoiaservice@va.gov<mailto:vacofoiaservice@va.gov>
Office of Government Information Services (OGIS)
Email Address: ogis@nara.gov<mailto:ogis@nara.gov>
Mailing address:
National Archives and Records Administration
8601 Adelphi Road
College Park, MD 20740-6001

FOIA Appeal
This concludes OSVA's Initial Agency Decision to request 25-08907-F.  Please be advised that should you desire to do so, you may appeal the determination made in this response to:
ogcfoiaappeals@va.gov<mailto:ogcfoiaappeals@va.gov>
Office of General Counsel (024)
Department of Veterans Affairs
810 Vermont Avenue, NW
Washington, DC 20420

If you should choose to file an appeal, please include a copy of this letter with your written appeal and clearly indicate the basis for your disagreement with the determination set forth in this response. Please be advised that in accordance with VA's implementing FOIA regulations at 38 C.F.R. § 1.559, your appeal must be postmarked no later than ninety (90) days of the date
of this letter.

Sincerely,

Richard Ha, JD, CIPP/G
OSVA FOIA Officer

Attachments - two (2) unredacted pages


Richard Ha
OSVA FOIA/Privacy Officer
Office of the Executive Secretary
Office of the Secretary, U.S. Dept. of Veterans Affairs (OSVA)
202-632-5286 o
202-309-3072 c
Richard.ha1@va.gov<mailto:Richard.ha1@va.gov>
OSVAFOIA@va.gov<mailto:OSVAFOIA@va.gov>

title: Sex Offender Registry and Community Supervision Request

communications.subject: Vermont Public Records Act Request: Sex Offender Registry and Community Supervision Request
communications.communication:
To Whom It May Concern:

Pursuant to the Vermont Public Records Act, I hereby request the following records:

And pursuant to Vt. Stat. Ann. tit. 1 §§ 315 to 320, I hereby request the following records:

The exact record of people who are 

1) on both the sex offender registry and probation; and
2) on both the sex offender registry and parole;

as per the latest available data. 

IF a list of names is not able to be provided, the exact number of people who are 

1) on both the sex offender registry and probation; and
2) on both the sex offender registry and parole;

as per the latest available data is requested.

If this data is held by another agency, I request the name of that agency.

The requested documents will be made available to the general public, and this request is not being made for commercial purposes.

In the event that there are fees, I would be grateful if you would inform me of the total charges in advance of fulfilling my request. I would prefer the request filled electronically, by e-mail attachment if available or CD-ROM if not.

Thank you in advance for your anticipated cooperation in this matter. I look forward to receiving your response to this request within 3 business days, as the statute requires.

Sincerely,

Wendy Sawyer

communications.subject: South Carolina Public Records Law Request: South Carolina DOC transgender policies
communications.communication:
To Whom It May Concern:

Pursuant to the South Carolina Public Records Law, I hereby request the following records:

All department policy and guidance documents regarding transgender inmates, including but not limited to gender-affirming medical care, housing and treatment by staff. I also request records of any proposed and/or enacted changes to said policies made on or after Nov. 6, 2024 until date of search, if such documents exist.

I request that, if appropriate, fees be waived as I believe this request is in the public interest. The requested documents will be made available to the general public free of charge as part of the public information service at MuckRock.com, processed by a representative of the news media/press and is made in the process of news gathering and not for commercial usage.

In the event that there are fees, I would be grateful if you would inform me of the total charges in advance of fulfilling my request. I would prefer the request filled electronically, by e-mail attachment if available or CD-ROM if not.

Thank you in advance for your anticipated cooperation in this matter. I look forward to receiving your response to this request within 15 business days, as the statute requires.

Sincerely,

Ileana Garnand

communications.subject: SCDC FOIA 0132-25 re: Transgender policies
communications.communication:
Ms. Garnand,
The South Carolina Department of Corrections is in receipt of your attached FOIA request regarding transgender policies, as of today, May 6, 2025. Your request has been assigned request number FOIA-0132-25. Please use this number in future correspondence regarding this request. As required by S.C. Code Ann. §30-4-30(C), you will receive a determination regarding the availability of these records within the applicable statutory timeframe.

Sincerely,​

SCDC FOIA Office​

Post Office Box 21787​

Columbia, SC 29221-1787​
FOIA@doc.sc.gov<mailto:FOIA@doc.sc.gov>

communications.subject: SCDC FOIA 0132-25 re: Transgender policies
communications.communication:
Ms. Garnand,

Pursuant to the South Carolina Freedom of Information Act’s requirement that we make public records available for “inspection or copying,” codified in SC Code Ann. 30-4-30(a), the SCDC non-restricted policies and procedures available on our website (https://doc.sc.gov/policy-disclaimer). You can also access them from our homepage (https://doc.sc.gov/) via the following steps:  Choose Policies under the About Us drop down menu on the top right corner. Once you accept the disclaimer, you will be able to choose the policies you are interested in from the list of SCDC policies.

The policies we believe are responsive to your request are:

A search in policy for “transgender inmates” produced four policies, which are listed below:

  *   OP-21.04, “Inmate Classification Plan;”
  *   OP-22.19, “Searches of Inmates;”
  *   GA-06.09, “Care and Custody of Transgender Inmates and Inmates Diagnosed with Gender Dysphoria;” and
  *   GA-06.11b, “Applying the Prison Rape Elimination Act (PREA)”
As the policies listed above are nonrestricted, copies of each policy have been submitted with this response. A revision and a change memorandum have been made to OP-21.04 since November 6, 2024. The most recent archived version of the policy along with the current version, which includes the changes from the full revision and change memorandum is also attached.

Sincerely,​

SCDC FOIA Office​

Post Office Box 21787​

Columbia, SC 29221-1787​
FOIA@doc.sc.gov<mailto:FOIA@doc.sc.gov>

communications.communication:
To Whom It May Concern:

Pursuant to the Washington Public Records Act, I hereby request the following records:

The following metadata for emails sent by Kylie Rolf (Kylie.Rolf@seattle.gov) between the dates of December 1, 2024 and March 3, 2025:
- Sender
- Recipient (To, CC, BCC)
- Date and time sent

As this is a request for metadata, please do not include the email body in the returned records.

In the event that there are fees, I would be grateful if you would inform me of the total charges in advance of fulfilling my request. I would prefer the request filled electronically, by e-mail attachment if available or CD-ROM if not.

Thank you in advance for your anticipated cooperation in this matter. I look forward to receiving your response to this request within 5 business days, as the statute requires.

Sincerely,

Rose Terse

communications.subject: Mayor's Office :: C217427-030325
communications.communication:
--- Please respond above this line --- 

Dear Rose Terse, 
Even though the Kylie Rolf is a Seattle Center employee, she reports to Greg Wong, who is a mayor's office employee. That is why the mayor's office has made the decision to keep this request with the mayor's office. In order for us to get the records you requested; a help ticket was made to IT to gather these records and provide them to us. Once we get the records, we will be conducting the review and releasing the records to you. The mayor's office will provide all metadata email FROM Kylie Rolf, per your request. 
Please note that the 2 requests you have sent to CEN have been closed because they are considered duplicates of this request. 
I hope this clears up any confusion. I am happy to chat over the phone if need be. 
Thank you 
Tracie Cantrell

communications.subject: City of Seattle Public Records Request Center - Invoice Ready :: C217427-030325
communications.communication:
Dear Rose Terse, 
 
Records in response to your public disclosure request C217427-030325 received on March 03, 2025 are now available. The cost for the records is as follows: 
 
Invoice Number: INV25-C217427-1 
Total: $1.25 
 
To pay online, please follow these steps: 
 Please note that you will need to disable any pop-up blockers to make a payment using the system. 
 
  * Navigate to the Public Records Request Center. 
  * Select 'My Records Request Center'. 
  * Select 'View My Requests'. You may be asked to login. 
  * Find this request: C217427-030325. 
  * Select the 'View Invoices' button. 
 
  * Opens a pop-up window showing your invoice: INV25-C217427-1. 
  * Click on the invoice and then the 'Pay Now' button. 
  * Continue processing your payment. 
  * Select 'Done'. 
  * Once the payment process is done, you are returned to the Public Records Request Center. 
  * After your payment is successful you will receive an email from our payments center. 
Once your payment has been approved, we will send you an email with instructions on how to download your records. Note that City staff must manually upload records. Records will be available one to two business days after payment. 
 
Please let your public disclosure officer (PDO) know if you are unable to pay online; your PDO will work with you on alternative ways to make your payment. 
 
You have 30 days from today's date to pay for your records. If the City does not receive your payment within this time period, your request will be considered abandoned, and you will need to submit a new request. 
 Please add seattle@mycusthelp.net to your E-mail contacts/address book to ensure delivery of the record center E-mails to your Inbox. (mailto:seattle@mycusthelp.net) 
This is an auto-generated email and has originated from an unmonitored email account. Please DO NOT REPLY.

Upload documents directly: https://accounts.muckrock.com/accounts/login/?next=https%3A%2F%2Fwww.muckrock.com%2Faccounts%2Flogin%2F%3Fnext%3D%252Faccounts%252Fagency_login%252Foffice-of-the-mayor-241%252Femail-metadata-kylie-rolf-182347%252F%253Femail%253DEXECPDR%252540seattle.gov&url_auth_token=AAAj9sYRrCpZzSYtO2LZl3Hncb4%3A1tpHZx%3AN6_k6UhNSbuqIiWuFJaaE7pyVf6k3U7GeGn2qocuWak 
The records being made available to you at this time include the following: Installment 1 
To download your records, please: 
 
  * Navigate to the Public Records Request Center. 
  * Select 'My Records Request Center'. 
  * Select 'View My Requests'. You may be asked to login. 
  * Select this request: C217427-030325. 
  * Select the 'View Files' button. 
  * You can download records individually or all at the same time by clicking 'Download All'. 
  *  Please save your records as you may only download them from the system three times. If you do not download your records within 30 days of request closure, the link to your records will expire. 
If you believe you have received privileged or confidential records in error, please notify the City of Seattle immediately, through the Public Records Request Center or by email. Privileged or confidential records provided or received in error should not be reviewed, used, disseminated, distributed, or copied, and should be destroyed immediately. Thank you in advance for your cooperation.  We have not prepared a detailed exemption log, as only limited information has been redacted from the responsive records. The information normally provided in an exemption log, such as title, author, recipient, subject, and number of pages, is readily ascertainable from looking at the redacted records. Redactions have been applied throughout the documents pursuant to the following exemption: Ex.01A- Attorney-Client Privileged Communications - RCW 42.56.070 and 5.60.060 - Records reflect communication between a client and an attorney for the purpose of seeking or providing legal advice. 

The Mayor's Office has now provided all responsive records. We consider your request closed and plan to take no further action to fulfill this request. If you have any follow-up questions or would like to initiate an administrative appeal under MDAR 17-0002 Section 6, please contact us within 10 business days after downloading your records, after which this request will no longer be monitored for communications. You may also seek judicial review of our response to your request for a period of one year, beginning as of the date of this message, consistent with RCW 42.56.550. 
Sincerely, 
Tracie Cantrell

communications.subject: Maryland Public Information Act Request: Luke Hill 2020 Attempted Murder case
communications.communication:
To Whom It May Concern:

Pursuant to the Maryland Public Information Act, I hereby request the following records:

All available records related to the case of Luke Hill, who was charged with attempted murder in May 2020. Specifically, I seek incident and arrest reports, charging documents, court records (including indictments, motions, and judgments), interrogation recordings or transcripts, evidence logs, witness statements, and any available video footage (e.g., body cam, dash cam, or surveillance). Please also include communications between law enforcement and prosecutors regarding this case. If any records are exempt from disclosure, please provide a detailed explanation for each exemption.

The requested documents will be made available to the general public, and this request is not being made for commercial purposes.

In the event that there are fees, I would be grateful if you would inform me of the total charges in advance of fulfilling my request. I would prefer the request filled electronically, by e-mail attachment if available or CD-ROM if not.

Thank you in advance for your anticipated cooperation in this matter. I look forward to receiving your response to this request within 10 calendar days, as the statute requires.

Sincerely,

Ore Adebanjo

communications.subject: RE: Maryland Public Information Act Request #M25-0033/ 20-0024421/ Luke Hill
communications.communication:
Dear Sgt. Zelaya,

I appreciate your time in reviewing my MPIA request. I understand that processing these requests requires significant effort, and I want to ensure mine is both reasonable and beneficial to the public.

My work focuses on highlighting real-world cases involving student-athletes to provide a learning tool for young players, parents, and coaches on the consequences of decision-making off the field. This request is not for commercial purposes but rather serves to inform and educate those invested in the development of young athletes.

Given that the Maryland Public Information Act allows for fee reductions when disclosure serves the public interest, I’d like to respectfully request a waiver or reduction of the fees associated with this request. If a full waiver isn’t possible, I’d be open to adjusting the scope of my request to minimize the cost while still obtaining the most essential information.

Please let me know if there’s any flexibility on this, or if there are modifications I can make to help facilitate the process. I truly appreciate your consideration and your time in handling this request.

Best,
Ore Adebanjo

communications.subject: RE: Maryland Public Information Act Request #M25-0033/ 20-0024421/ Luke Hill
communications.communication:
Mr. Adebanjo,

After speaking to the Director,  we will not be able to grant you a waiver for fees associated from your MPIA Request. It took a lot of time and effort to get the case file you were requesting.  We do not waive fees for media organizations.  Our local media outlets, NBC, FOX, ABC, CBS are also required to pay for their MPIA information.

Let me know how you want to proceed.


1st Sgt. Julio Zelaya #2165
Prince George’s County Police Department
Records Management Division- MPIA Unit
4923 43rd Avenue
Hyattsville Md. 20781

communications.subject: California Public Records Act Request: SB1421/SB16 DA "Memos" San Bernardino DA
communications.communication:
Mr. Schultze, 

To simplify our case, I am submitting a new request for the release of records under the California Public Records Act, Gov’t Code §§ 7920.000 et seq., California Penal Code §§832.7-832.8, and Art. I, § 3(b) of the California Constitution.  I seek copies of all records in your office’s possession, regardless of who created them. This request is for all District Attorney’s Office “investigative reports,” which you call “memoranda,” summarizing your office’s investigations and conclusions regarding 165 officer-involved shootings and other use-of-force incidents resulting in serious bodily injury or death occurring in San Bernardino County between 2014-2024 listed in the attached csv. It includes incidents previously identified by your office, which are labeled in the “Data From” column as “DA List.” 

Please respond to this request in ten days, either by providing the requested information or providing a written response setting forth the specific legal authority on which you rely in failing to disclose each requested record, or by specifying a date in the near future to respond to the request. See Cal. Gov’t Code § 7922. Pursuant to section 7922.600, please disclose all reasonably segregable non-exempt information from any portions of records you claim are exempt from disclosure.

If any records requested above are available in electronic format, please provide them in an electronic format, as provided in Govt. Code § 7922.570. To assist with the prompt release of responsive material, we ask that you make records available to us as you locate them, rather than waiting until all responsive records have been collected and copied.     
 
Thank you for your assistance with this routine request.
 
Sincerely,
 
Katey Rusch
Reporter, Investigative Reporting Program at UC-Berkeley
(510) 516-6277

communications.subject: RE: California Public Records Act Request: San Bernardino County District Attorney 2024 SB1421/SB16 Request
communications.communication:
Ms. Rusch,

Just to provide a brief update.

I have gotten through roughly the first 50 names on your spreadsheet. I already have .pdf files of 6 public memoranda that were released, but are simply no longer on our website. (They were all publicly released prior to April of 2020, which is as far back as the news releases on the site go.)

I believe there are likely many more public memoranda, but we will need to find the hard copies. In the past, the memoranda were in each office, rather than centralized.

I am about to start a two-week evidentiary hearing on a habeas corpus case, which will slow my progress. However, I will have our paralegal start looking for the hard copies.

Cordially,

Brent Schultze
Lead Deputy District Attorney
Appellate Services Unit
San Bernardino County District Attorney's Office
303 W. Third Street, Fifth Floor
San Bernardino, CA, 92415-0511

communications.subject: RE: California Public Records Act Request: SB1421/SB16 DA "Memos" San Bernardino DA
communications.communication:
Hi Mr. Schultze, 

Thank you for your response and for quickly reviewing the first 50 names. We would like copies of the six public memoranda sent to us by March 28, 2025. As is spelled out in the request, we are requesting to receive records on a rolling basis. As for the remaining review of responsive records, I have a few requests for clarification: 

1) On the remaining 44 names you have reviewed, are you still looking for memoranda on all 44? Or have you determined that responsive memoranda for specific incidents are exempt from disclosure? If you have determined any responsive records are exempt from disclosure, as noted in our request, we expect the legally required determination. 
2) On the other 63 cases you have yet to review that are NOT “Currently Under Review,” when do you plan to make a determination whether or not you have disclosable responsive records? As a reminder, the 10-day determination requirement in Cal Govt. Code § 7922.535 was Friday 3/14/25 (the request was sent on the evening of 3/3/25 making the date of receipt 3/4/25). 
3) On the 52 cases “Currently Under Review,” we expect the required updates on those responsive records as spelled out in Cal. Penal Code § 832.7(b)(8). 

As always, we are happy to answer your questions and look forward to the department's prompt response to this narrowed request. 

Best, 

Katey Rusch
(510) 516-6277
California Reporting Project

Cordially,

Brent Schultze

title: Library Contract Request: ACS Journals at San Diego City College

communications.subject: California Public Records Act Request: Library Contract Request: ACS Journals at San Diego City College
communications.communication:
To Whom It May Concern:

Pursuant to the California Public Records Act, I hereby request the following records:

The most recent governing, base, or master license with the American Chemical Society (ACS) relating to the licensing of ACS Journals;
All related amendments, addenda, appendices, attachments, product terms, MOUs, MOAs, data processing agreements, and/or letters of intent; and
All financial documents or records of financial transactions, exchanges or obligations related to the contractual relations with ACS for journal licensing. Responsive materials include invoices, order forms, and any other documents that incorporate language governing terms of use of the ACS Journals.

If you contend that any portion of the records requested is exempt from disclosure by express provisions of law, Government Code § 7922.525(b) requires segregation and redaction of that material in order that the remainder of the records may be released. If you contend that any express provision of law exists to exempt from disclosure all or a portion of the records I have requested, Government Code § 7922.535 requires that you notify me of the reasons for the determination not later than 10 days from your receipt of this request. Government Code § 7922.540 requires that any response to this request that includes a determination that the request is denied, in whole or in part, must be in writing and include the name and title of the person(s) responsible for the institution’s response.

I am affiliated with an educational research institution; this request is made for a scholarly purpose.

The requested documents will be made available to the general public, and this request is not being made for commercial purposes.

In the event that there are fees, I would be grateful if you would inform me of the total charges in advance of fulfilling my request. I would prefer the request filled electronically, by e-mail attachment if available or CD-ROM if not.

Thank you in advance for your anticipated cooperation in this matter. I look forward to receiving your response to this request within 10 calendar days, as the statute requires.

Sincerely,

mo

communications.subject: RE: California Public Records Act Request #CPR0367
communications.communication:
I appreciate you sending these documents; however, they are not fully responsive to my request. I'm not seeking pricing information; rather, I'm seeking the terms & conditions governing the use of the ACS Journals at San Diego City College. Therefore, responsive materials should include the underlying/governing contract or license agreement, in addition to other amendments, appendices, order forms, etc. that contain terms of use.

It's possible that the library does not have a direct contractual relationship with ACS, but rather subscribes through a consortium such as California Digital Library or SCELC. However, the library should still have a copy of the contract, as it governs their use of ACS journals. Please check again for a contract with ACS, including any consortial contract that lists San Diego City College as a participating institution.

Thank you for your prompt assistance!

communications.subject: Montana Freedom of Information Act Request: Montana DOC transgender policies
communications.communication:
To Whom It May Concern:

Pursuant to the Montana Freedom of Information Act, I hereby request the following records:

All department policy and guidance documents regarding transgender inmates, including but not limited to gender-affirming medical care, housing and treatment by staff. I also request records of any proposed and/or enacted changes to said policies made on or after Nov. 6, 2024 until date of search, if such documents exist.

I request that, if appropriate, fees be waived as I believe this request is in the public interest. The requested documents will be made available to the general public free of charge as part of the public information service at MuckRock.com, processed by a representative of the news media/press and is made in the process of news gathering and not for commercial usage.

In the event that there are fees, I would be grateful if you would inform me of the total charges in advance of fulfilling my request. I would prefer the request filled electronically, by e-mail attachment if available or CD-ROM if not.

Thank you in advance for your anticipated cooperation in this matter. I look forward to receiving your response to this request within 10 business days.

Sincerely,

Ileana Garnand

communications.subject: California Public Records Act Request: Police Settlements (Inglewood City Attorney)
communications.communication:
To Whom It May Concern:

Pursuant to the California Public Records Act, I hereby request the following records:

Copies of all reports, lists, databases, or individual documents created since 1/1/16 detail lawsuits brought against the city's police department. This should include any documentation mechanism your department uses to track lawsuits. It should also include any documents your department submits to local, state, or federal agencies listing the number and/or status of lawsuits brought against the police department.

This request should be construed to include documents compiled quarterly, annually, or in other increments as well as documents or databases that contain responsive information over a longer time span.

Please provide all available materials from January 1, 2016 through November 6, 2024.

title: Marines support for 2023 documentary "Brothers After War"

communications.subject: Freedom of Information Act Request: Marines support for 2023 documentary "Brothers After War"
communications.communication:
To Whom It May Concern:

Pursuant to the Freedom of Information Act, I hereby request the following records:

All documents pertaining to collaboration between the U.S. Marine Corps and the production of the 2023 documentary "Brothers After War" directed by Jake Rademacher and written by David Paluck. I request any and all documents pertaining to Marines support for "Brothers After War." Such documents may include but should not be limited to: script notes; production assistance agreements; and all records of communications between employees of the Marines and members of the cast, crew, and production company of "Brothers After War," including memos, notes of meetings and conference calls, emails, and other forms of communication.

I am the Director of Research Operations at a 501(c)(3) non-profit organization called The Decoding Culture Foundation as well as the editor-in-chief and a contributor to a research magazine published by said foundation titled "Cultural Engineering Studies." These documents will be used for public education and research purposes. I therefore request a waiver of all fees that may otherwise apply. Attached is a document with organization letterhead confirming my position, as well as the organization's 501(c)(3) application and approval form.

The requested documents will be made available to the general public, and this request is not being made for commercial purposes.

In the event that there are fees, I would be grateful if you would inform me of the total charges in advance of fulfilling my request. I would prefer the request filled electronically, by e-mail attachment if available or CD-ROM if not.

Thank you in advance for your anticipated cooperation in this matter. I look forward to receiving your response to this request within 20 business days, as the statute requires.

Sincerely,

Brett Carollo

communications.subject: Florida Sunshine Law Request: Florida DOC transgender policies
communications.communication:
To Whom It May Concern:

Pursuant to the Florida Sunshine Law, I hereby request the following records:

All department policy and guidance documents regarding transgender inmates, including but not limited to gender-affirming medical care, housing and treatment by staff. I also request records of any proposed and/or enacted changes to said policies made on or after Nov. 6, 2024 until date of search, if such documents exist.

I request that, if appropriate, fees be waived as I believe this request is in the public interest. The requested documents will be made available to the general public free of charge as part of the public information service at MuckRock.com, processed by a representative of the news media/press and is made in the process of news gathering and not for commercial usage.

In the event that there are fees, I would be grateful if you would inform me of the total charges in advance of fulfilling my request. I would prefer the request filled electronically, by e-mail attachment if available or CD-ROM if not.

Thank you in advance for your anticipated cooperation in this matter. I look forward to receiving your response to this request within 10 business days.

Sincerely,

Ileana Garnand

Dear Ileana Garnand: 
 
Thank you for your interest in public records of the Florida Department of Corrections. Your request has been received and is being processed. Your request was received in this office on 5/6/2025 10:25:59 PM and given the reference number R038414-050625 for tracking purposes.  Please be advised that your request will be processed in the order of receipt. If you need to update your request, please respond to this email advising what you need updated.  Also, please do not send the same request using different methods to transmit the request (mail, fax, phone, etc.), or to different offices or institutions as this will slow down the process as well. The same custodians will work on your request no matter how or where it is submitted.  We are unable to expedite requests. Please do not submit duplicate requests, as this will only slow down the process. Records Requested: To Whom It May Concern: 

Pursuant to the Florida Sunshine Law, I hereby request the following records: 

All department policy and guidance documents regarding transgender inmates, including but not limited to gender-affirming medical care, housing and treatment by staff. I also request records of any proposed and/or enacted changes to said policies made on or after Nov. 6, 2024 until date of search, if such documents exist. 

I request that, if appropriate, fees be waived as I believe this request is in the public interest. The requested documents will be made available to the general public free of charge as part of the public information service at MuckRock.com, processed by a representative of the news media/press and is made in the process of news gathering and not for commercial usage. 

In the event that there are fees, I would be grateful if you would inform me of the total charges in advance of fulfilling my request. I would prefer the request filled electronically, by e-mail attachment if available or CD-ROM if not. 

Thank you in advance for your anticipated cooperation in this matter. I look forward to receiving your response to this request within 10 business days. 

Sincerely, 

Ileana Garnand

communications.subject: Freedom of Information Act Request: SolarApp+ Lobbying (National Renewable Energy Laboratory)
communications.communication:
To Whom It May Concern:

Pursuant to the Freedom of Information Act, I hereby request the following records:

1. Emails or equivalent communication between anyone concerning any bill or legislation requiring state-wide mandates for/or adoption of SolarApp+ software.
2. Emails or equivalent communication between anyone at concerning any funding opportunities concerning  the adoption of SolarApp+ software and the funding amounts.
3. Actual funding amounts provided either for the development of SolarAPP+ by an individuals or agencies or to the SolarAPP Foundation by any agency.

The requested documents will be made available to the general public, and this request is not being made for commercial purposes.

In the event that there are fees, I would be grateful if you would inform me of the total charges in advance of fulfilling my request. I would prefer the request filled electronically, by e-mail attachment if available or CD-ROM if not.

Thank you in advance for your anticipated cooperation in this matter. I look forward to receiving your response to this request within 20 business days, as the statute requires.

Sincerely,

Ramon Vega

communications.subject: Freedom of Information Act Request: Singh Mortality Review
communications.communication:
To Whom It May Concern:

Pursuant to the Freedom of Information Act, I hereby request the following records:

A copy of the IHSC Mortality Review for Jaspar Singh, who died in ICE Custody April 15, 2024, according to the Detainee Death Report ICE published: https://www.ice.gov/doclib/foia/reports/ddrSinghJaspar.pdf

I make this request as a member of the media, and therefore seek a fee waiver. Representative edited works based on prior FOIA requests like this one may be reviewed here: https://theappeal.org/authors/andrew-free/; and here: https://atlpresscollective.com/2025/01/31/new-record-sheds-light-on-unreported-death-in-atlanta-airport-customs-inspection/. 

I request expedited processing of this request pursuant to 6 CFR 5.5(e) and attest under penalty of perjury pursuant to 28 USC 1746 that the following statements are true and correct to the best of my knowledge and understanding: 
1. ICE deaths in custody in FY25 are currently on track to equal or surpass the 12 deaths in the previous fiscal year. 

2. IHSC Mortality Reviews provide an authoritative agency accounting of the medical circumstances of in-custody deaths. These reviews often conflict with the public-facing story the agency tells, raising critical questions about accountability, transparency, waste, fraud, and abuse. See https://phr.org/our-work/resources/deadly-failures-preventable-deaths-in-u-s-immigration-detention/.

3. The current administration's expansion of federal immigration detention is the subject of widespread and exceptional media interest in which there exist possible questions about the government's integrity which affect public confidence. See, e.g., 
a. https://www.newyorker.com/news/the-lede/how-many-immigrants-will-die-in-us-custody
b. https://www.reviewjournal.com/news/politics-and-government/nevada/ice-increases-detention-capacity-in-southern-nevada-3318591/&ct=ga&cd=CAEYAioTODA4NDM3NjM3MDcwNDg3MjU0NDIaMzU4OGE4OGMwMWViNjNlYTpjb206ZW46VVM&usg=AOvVaw0AY_z02AvW4eN7-HW7Pbvr
c. https://www.reviewjournal.com/news/politics-and-government/nevada/ice-increases-detention-capacity-in-southern-nevada-3318591/
d. https://www.leavenworthtimes.com/kansas-politicians-say-an-awful-lot-but-look-beyond-those-words/
e. https://latenighter.com/news/john-oliver-shares-chilling-details-about-ice-detention/
f. https://www.bisnow.com/national/news/capital-markets/private-prison-firms-predict-unprecedented-growth-from-trumps-immigration-crackdown-128291
g. https://www.wkbn.com/news/local-news/youngstown-news/corecivic-trying-to-add-space-for-ice-detainees/
h. https://prismreports.org/2025/01/15/biden-immigration-migrant-deaths/
i. https://prismreports.org/2024/06/25/nearly-all-deaths-in-ice-detention-over-5-years-were-preventable/
j. https://www.kcbd.com/2025/03/11/garza-county-now-reviewing-proposals-interested-giles-w-dalby-correctional-facility-operators/
k. https://capitalandmain.com/more-people-in-ice-custody-means-smaller-meals-and-delayed-medical-care-detainees-say
l. https://www.theguardian.com/world/2025/mar/11/german-tourists-ordeal-reportedly-ending-returned-from-us-detention
m. https://www.denverpost.com/2025/03/11/denver-ice-expand-detention-capacity-colorado-wyoming/
n. https://www.aclufl.org/en/press-releases/three-deaths-ice-custody-just-over-month-trumps-presidency-marks-most-deaths-occur
o. https://www.seattletimes.com/nation-world/nation/privately-run-immigration-detention-center-that-previously-held-families-in-texas-will-reopen/
p. https://www.natchezdemocrat.com/2025/03/05/a-city-within-a-city-wardens-at-adams-county-correctional-discuss-benefits-challenges-of-max-occupancy-at-ice-facility/
q. https://www.goodmorningamerica.com/news/live-updates/trump-2nd-term-live-updates-va-prepares-to-cut-as-many-as-72000-employees-in-next-wave-of-layoffs-memo-119377651
r. https://www.washingtonpost.com/immigration/2025/03/05/dilley-texas-family-detention-center-ice/
s. https://finance.yahoo.com/news/corecivic-announces-resumption-operations-south-211500232.html
t. https://www.spokesman.com/stories/2025/mar/04/for-profit-kansas-prison-with-troubled-history-cou/
u. https://www.motherjones.com/politics/2025/03/private-prison-mass-deportation-trump-billions-geogroup-corecivic-ice/
v. https://filtermag.org/trump-deportations-private-prisons/amp/
w. https://www.axios.com/2025/03/06/corecivic-immigrant-family-detention-center-texas
x. https://theappeal.org/mahmoud-khalil-lasalle-detention-center-louisiana/
y. https://law.yale.edu/yls-today/news/students-document-reports-abuse-immigration-detention-center
z. https://www.investigativepost.org/2025/02/20/521935/

The requested documents will be made available to the general public, and this request is not being made for commercial purposes.

In the event that there are fees, I would be grateful if you would inform me of the total charges in advance of fulfilling my request. I would prefer the request filled electronically, by e-mail attachment if available or CD-ROM if not.

Thank you in advance for your anticipated cooperation in this matter. I look forward to receiving your response to this request within 20 business days, as the statute requires.

Sincerely,

Andrew Free

communications.subject: ICE FOIA 2025-ICFO-25068
communications.communication:
03/13/2025 

Andrew  Free 
MuckRock News, DEPT MR182995 
Boston, Massachusetts 02115 

RE:	ICE FOIA Case Number 2025-ICFO-25068 
 
Dear Requester: 

This acknowledges receipt of your Freedom of Information Act (FOIA) request to U.S. Immigration and Customs Enforcement (ICE), dated 3/13/2025, your request for a waiver of all assessable FOIA fees, and your request for expedited treatment. Your request was received in this office on 3/13/2025. Specifically, you have requested records pertaining to a copy of the IHSC Mortality Review for Jaspar Singh, who died in ICE Custody April 15, 2024, according to the Detainee Death Report ICE published: https://www.ice.gov/doclib/foia/reports/ddrSinghJaspar.pdf. 

Due to the increasing number of FOIA requests received by this office, we may encounter some delay in processing your request. Per Section 5.5(a) of the DHS FOIA regulations, 6 C.F.R. Part 5, ICE processes FOIA requests according to their order of receipt. Although ICE’s goal is to respond within 20 business days of receipt of your request, the FOIA does permit a 10-day extension of this time period. As your request seeks numerous documents that will necessitate a thorough and wide-ranging search, ICE will invoke a 10-day extension for your request, as allowed by Title 5 U.S.C. § 552(a)(6)(B). If you’re able to narrow the scope of your request please contact our office. Narrowing the scope may speed up the search process. We will make every effort to comply with your request in a timely manner. 

Your request for expedited treatment is hereby denied. 

Under the DHS FOIA regulations, expedited processing of a FOIA request is warranted if the request involves “circumstances in which the lack of expedited treatment could reasonably be expected to pose an imminent threat to the life or physical safety of an individual,” 6 C.F.R. § 5.5(e)(1)(i), or “an urgency to inform the public about an actual or alleged federal government activity, if made by a person primarily engaged in disseminating information,” 6 C.F.R. § 5.5(e)(l)(ii).  Requesters seeking expedited processing must submit a statement explaining in detail the basis for the request, and that statement must be certified by the requester to be true and correct.  6 C.F.R. § 5.5(e)(3). 

Your request for expedited processing is denied because you do not qualify for either category under 6 C.F.R. § 5.5(e)(1).  You failed to demonstrate a particular urgency to inform the public about the government activity involved in the request beyond the public’s right to know about government activity generally.  Your letter was conclusory in nature and did not present any facts to justify a grant of expedited processing under the applicable standards. 

After thoroughly reviewing your letter and request for fee waiver, I have determined that you have not presented a convincing argument that you and/or your organization is entitled to a blanket waiver of applicable fees. 

The DHS FOIA Regulations at 6 CFR § 5.11(k)(2) set forth six factors to examine in determining whether the applicable legal standard for a fee waiver has been met.  We will consider these factors in our evaluation of your request for a fee waiver: 

(1) Whether the subject of the requested records concerns “the operations or activities of the government”; 
(2) Whether the disclosure is “likely to contribute” to an understanding of government operations or activities; 
(3) Whether disclosure of the requested information will contribute to the understanding of the public at large, as opposed to the individual understanding of the requestor or a narrow segment of interested persons; 
(4) Whether the contribution to public understanding of government operations or activities will be "significant"; 
(5) Whether the requester has a commercial interest that would be furthered by the requested disclosure; and 
(6) Whether the magnitude of any identified commercial interest to the requestor is sufficiently large in comparison with the public interest in disclosure, that disclosure is primarily in the commercial interest of the requestor. 

As a requester, you bear the burden under FOIA of showing that the fee waiver requirements have been met.  Based on my review of your 3/13/2025 letter and for the reasons stated herein, I have determined that your fee waiver request is deficient because your request did not satisfy factors 1, 2, 3, 4, 5, and 6. Since your request for a fee waiver has failed to satisfy each of the required factors, I am denying your fee waiver request. 

Provisions of the FOIA allow us to recover part of the cost of complying with your request.  We shall charge you for records in accordance with the DHS Interim FOIA regulations, as they apply to media requesters.  As a media requester, you will be charged 10 cents per page for duplication; the first 100 pages are free.  We will construe the submission of your request as an agreement to pay up to $25.00. You will be contacted before any further fees are accrued. 

If you deem the decision to deny expedited treatment and fee waiver for your request an adverse determination, you have the right to appeal.  Should you wish to do so, you must send your appeal and a copy of this letter, within 90 days of the date of this letter following the procedures outlined in the DHS FOIA regulations at 6 C.F.R. Part 5 § 5.5(e)(2). You may submit your appeal electronically at GILDFOIAAppeals@ice.dhs.gov or via regular mail to: 

U.S. Immigration and Customs Enforcement 
Office of the Principal Legal Advisor 
U.S. Department of Homeland Security 
500 12th Street,, S.W., Mail Stop 5900 
Washington, D.C. 20536-5900 

Your envelope and letter should be marked “FOIA Appeal.”  Copies of the FOIA and DHS regulations are available at www.dhs.gov/foia. 

ICE has queried the appropriate program offices within ICE for responsive records. If any responsive records are located, they will be reviewed for determination of releasability. Please be assured that one of the processors in our office will respond to your request as expeditiously as possible. We appreciate your patience as we proceed with your request. 

If you have any questions please contact FOIA Public Liaison Daniel Edgington, at (866) 633-1182 or 500 12th St, SW Stop 5009 Washington, DC 20536-5009. Additionally, you have a right to seek dispute resolution services from the Office of Government Information Services (OGIS) which mediates disputes between FOIA requesters and Federal agencies as a non-exclusive alternative to litigation.  If you are requesting access to your own records (which is considered a Privacy Act request), you should know that OGIS does not have the authority to handle requests made under the Privacy Act of 1974.  You may contact OGIS as follows:  Office of Government Information Services, National Archives and Records Administration, 8601 Adelphi Road-OGIS, College Park, Maryland 20740-6001, e-mail at ogis@nara.gov; telephone at 202-741-5770; toll free at 1-877-684-6448. 

Your request has been assigned reference number 2025-ICFO-25068. Please use this number in future correspondence. 

Sincerely, 

ICE FOIA Office 
Immigration and Customs Enforcement 
Freedom of Information Act Office 
500 12th Street, S.W., Stop 5009 
Washington, D.C. 20536-5009

communications.subject: ICE FOIA 2025-ICFO-25068
communications.communication:
5/19/2025 

Andrew Free 
Muck Rock News, DEPT MR182995 
263 Huntington Ave 
Boston, Massachusetts 02115 

RE:	ICE FOIA Case Number 2025-ICFO-25068 

Dear Requester: 

This letter is the final response to your Freedom of Information Act (FOIA) request to U.S. Immigration and Customs Enforcement (ICE), dated 3/13/2025.  You have requested records pertaining to a copy of the IHSC Mortality Review for Jaspar Singh, who died in ICE Custody April 15, 2024, according to the Detainee Death Report ICE published: https://www.ice.gov/doclib/foia/reports/ddrSinghJaspar.pdf. ICE has considered your request under the FOIA, 5 U.S.C. § 552. 

ICE considered the foreseeable harm standard when reviewing the record set and has applied the FOIA exemptions as required by the statute and the Attorney General’s Guidance. 

A search of the ICE Offices of Enforcement and Removal Operations (ERO) and Office of Professional Responsibility (OPR) for records responsive to your request produced 8 pages that are responsive to your request.  After review of those documents, I have determined portions of 8 pages will be withheld pursuant to Exemptions of the FOIA as described below. 
ICE has applied FOIA Exemptions 6 and 7(C) to protect from disclosure the names, e-mail addresses, and phone numbers of DHS employees, as well as other third-party information contained within the documents. 

FOIA Exemption 6 exempts from disclosure personnel or medical files and similar files the release of which would cause a clearly unwarranted invasion of personal privacy.  This requires a balancing of the public’s right to disclosure against the individual’s right to privacy.  The privacy interests of the individuals in the records you have requested outweigh any minimal public interest in disclosure of the information.  Any private interest you may have in that information does not factor into the aforementioned balancing test. 

FOIA Exemption 7(C) protects records or information compiled for law enforcement purposes that could reasonably be expected to constitute an unwarranted invasion of personal privacy.  This exemption takes particular note of the strong interests of individuals, whether they are suspects, witnesses, or investigators, in not being unwarrantably associated with alleged criminal activity.  That interest extends to persons who are not only the subjects of the investigation, but those who may have their privacy invaded by having their identities and information about them revealed in connection with an investigation.  Based upon the traditional recognition of strong privacy interest in law enforcement records, categorical withholding of information that identifies third parties in law enforcement records is ordinarily appropriate.  As such, I have determined that the privacy interest in the identities of individuals in the records you have requested clearly outweigh any minimal public interest in disclosure of the information.  Please note that any private interest you may have in that information does not factor into this determination. 

You have a right to appeal the above withholding determination.  Should you wish to do so, you must send your appeal and a copy of this letter, within 90 days of the date of this letter following the procedures outlined in the DHS FOIA regulations at 6 C.F.R. Part 5 § 5.8. You may submit your appeal electronically at GILDFOIAAppeals@ice.dhs.gov or via regular mail to: 

U.S. Immigration and Customs Enforcement 
Office of the Principal Legal Advisor 
U.S. Department of Homeland Security 
500 12th Street, S.W., Mail Stop 5900 
Washington, D.C. 20536-5900 

Your envelope and letter should be marked “FOIA Appeal.”  Copies of the FOIA and DHS regulations are available at www.dhs.gov/foia. 

Provisions of FOIA allow DHS to charge for processing fees, up to $25, unless you seek a waiver of fees.  In this instance, because the cost is below the $25 minimum, there is no charge. 

If you have any questions, please contact FOIA Public Liaison Daniel Edgington at (866) 633-1182 or 500 12th St., SW Stop 5009 Washington, DC 20536-5009.  Additionally, you have a right to right to seek dispute resolution services from the Office of Government Information Services (OGIS) which mediates disputes between FOIA requesters and Federal agencies as a non-exclusive alternative to litigation.  If you are requesting access to your own records (which is considered a Privacy Act request), you should know that OGIS does not have the authority to handle requests made under the Privacy Act of 1974.  You may contact OGIS as follows:  Office of Government Information Services, National Archives and Records Administration, 8601 Adelphi Road-OGIS, College Park, Maryland 20740-6001, e-mail at ogis@nara.gov; telephone at 202-741-5770; toll free at 1-877-684-6448. 

Sincerely, 

Megan Davis 
Deputy FOIA Officer, Operations

Sincerely,

Joey Scott

communications.subject: New York Freedom of Information Law Request: Library Contract Request: Westlaw at SUNY Binghamton
communications.communication:
To Whom It May Concern:

Pursuant to the New York Freedom of Information Law, I hereby request the following records:

The most recent contract, governing, base, or master license agreement with Thomson Reuters relating to the licensing of the Westlaw Campus Research database; and
All related terms and conditions, terms of service, amendments, addenda, appendices, attachments, product terms, MOUs, MOAs, data processing agreements, and/or letters of intent; and
All financial documents or records of financial transactions, exchanges or obligations with language governing the use of the Westlaw Campus Research database.
Responsive materials include all contracts, agreements, amendments, appendices, invoices, and any other documents listed above that incorporate language governing terms of use of the Westlaw Campus Research database.

The requested documents will be made available to the general public, and this request is not being made for commercial purposes.

In the event that there are fees, I would be grateful if you would inform me of the total charges in advance of fulfilling my request. I would prefer the request filled electronically, by e-mail attachment if available or CD-ROM if not.

Thank you in advance for your anticipated cooperation in this matter. I look forward to receiving your response to this request within 5 business days, as the statute requires.

Sincerely,

mo

communications.subject: RE: New York Freedom of Information Law Request #FOIL-2023-019-00037
communications.communication:
Dear Records Access Officer:

This is an appeal of the OMB's determination on 9/12/24, regarding the above request. The OMB has constructively denied my request. The possible return date of 11/15/24 -- more than a year after the request was filed – is unreasonable, given the narrow scope of the request.

Because of this appeal, the OMB is required by law to provide specific reasons within 10 business days explaining why this request cannot be filled, or else, must provide the records sought.

According to the Committee on Open Government, if a government entity acknowledges that a request has been received, but has failed to grant access by the specific date given beyond twenty business days, or if the specific date given is unreasonable, a request may be considered to have been constructively denied (see §89[4][a]).  In such a circumstance, the denial may be appealed in accordance with §89(4)(a), which states in relevant part that:

“...any person denied access to a record may within thirty days appeal in writing such denial to the head, chief executive or governing body of the entity, or the person therefore designated by such head, chief executive, or governing body, who shall within ten business days of the receipt of such appeal fully explain in writing to the person requesting the record the reasons for further denial, or provide access to the record sought.” 

I, on behalf of New York Focus, am requesting either you fill this FOIL request, or else provide a full explanation as to the reason for the denial, as required by law, of this public record.

Sincerely,
Sam Mellins
Senior Reporter, New York Focus

communications.subject: [OpenRecords] Note Added to FOIL-2023-019-00037
communications.communication:
Attention Office of Management and Budget (MOMB) Users, The following note was added to FOIL-2023-019-00037 by the requester: (https://a860-openrecords.nyc.gov/request/view/FOIL-2023-019-00037)

Dear Records Access Officer:

This is an appeal of the OMB's determination on 9/12/24, regarding the above request. The OMB has constructively denied my request. The possible return date of 11/15/24 -- more than a year after the request was filed – is unreasonable, given the narrow scope of the request.

Because of this appeal, the OMB is required by law to provide specific reasons within 10 business days explaining why this request cannot be filled, or else, must provide the records sought.

According to the Committee on Open Government, if a government entity acknowledges that a request has been received, but has failed to grant access by the specific date given beyond twenty business days, or if the specific date given is unreasonable, a request may be considered to have been constructively denied (see §89[4][a]). In such a circumstance, the denial may be appealed in accordance with §89(4)(a), which states in relevant part that:

“...any person denied access to a record may within thirty days appeal in writing such denial to the head, chief executive or governing body of the entity, or the person therefore designated by such head, chief executive, or governing body, who shall within ten business days of the receipt of such appeal fully explain in writing to the person requesting the record the reasons for further denial, or provide access to the record sought.”

I, on behalf of New York Focus, am requesting either you fill this FOIL request, or else provide a full explanation as to the reason for the denial, as required by law, of this public record.

Sincerely,
Sam Mellins
Senior Reporter, New York Focus
